questions.q: I'm completely new to tarot. Where do I start?
questions.a:
Start simple and build gradually:

  • Begin with daily single-card pulls - Pull one card each morning and reflect on how its energy shows up in your day
  • Focus on the imagery first - What do you see? What emotions does it evoke? Trust your initial impressions
  • Then reference the guidebook - Compare your intuitive read with traditional meanings
  • Journal your interpretations - Track how your understanding evolves

Don't try to memorize all 78 cards at once. Our guidebook includes a structured learning path that introduces cards in manageable groups, starting with the Major Arcana's 22 cards before moving to the suits.

questions.q: Do I need to be "psychic" or "intuitive" to read tarot?
questions.a:
No. While some readers incorporate psychic abilities, tarot works equally well as a psychological tool, creative prompt, or decision-making framework. The cards create a structured space for reflection—the insight comes from your own wisdom, not supernatural ability.

Many successful tarot readers approach the practice completely secularly, using the archetypal imagery to unlock perspectives they already possess but haven't consciously accessed.

questions.q: How long does it take to learn tarot divination?
questions.a:
You can give meaningful readings from day one, even if they're simple. Most people feel comfortable with:

  • Single-card pulls: Immediately
  • Three-card spreads: Within 2-4 weeks
  • Complex spreads: 3-6 months
  • Reading professionally for others: 1-2 years of regular practice

The Hermetic Flight's visual storytelling accelerates this timeline by making card meanings more immediately accessible than text-heavy or abstract decks.

questions.q: Should I learn reversed card meanings?
questions.a:
That's completely up to you—there's no "right" answer. Some readers use reversals, others don't. Both approaches are valid.

Arguments against learning reversals initially:

  • You're already learning 78 cards; don't double your workload unnecessarily
  • Many professional readers never use reversals and read beautifully
  • You can always add reversals later if desired

Arguments for learning reversals:

  • Adds nuance and depth to readings
  • Helps identify blocked or internalized energy
  • Some spreads benefit from directional indicators

Our guidebook includes reversed meanings for those who want them, but frames them as optional rather than required.

questions.q: What's the deal with court cards? Everyone says they're confusing.
questions.a:
Court cards (Pages, Knights, Queens, Kings) are notoriously tricky because they can represent:

  • Actual people in your life
  • Aspects of your own personality
  • Situational approaches or energy
  • Messages or stages of development

The Hermetic Flight addresses this confusion through distinct physical embodiment. Each court card features a performer whose presence, movement quality, and energy clearly conveys whether you're encountering:

  • Page energy (curious, learning, grounded exploration)
  • Knight energy (dynamic action, forward momentum)
  • Queen energy (mastery, internal authority)
  • King energy (external authority, established power)

The guidebook includes a dedicated court card section with specific guidance on determining which interpretation applies in context.
